elements.content: An acetate-functionalized purine-containing ligand, 2-(6-oxo-6,9-dihydro-1H-purin-1-yl) acetic acid (H 2 L), and its six new one–three-dimensional (1–3D) coordination polymers, [La(HL)2(NO3)(H2O)2] n (1), [Ce(HL)2(NO3)(H2O)2] n (2), [Pb(HL)2(H2O)2] n (3), [Cd(HL)2(H2O)2] n (4), [Cd(L)] n (5), and [Zn(L)] n (6), were synthesized and characterized. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses reveal that the architectures of complexes 1–6 are built from the metal–organic helixes of ligands H 2 L. The overall structures range from the double helical chains of 1 and 2, and the 2D helical networks of 3 and 4, to the 3D coordination polymers of 5 and 6, containing 2D homochiral layers based on 1D metal–organic helixes. In those meso compounds, ligands H 2 L display differently anionic states, bridge modes, and especially unsymmetrical configurations with the sharp distortion between the acetate and purin in favor of constructing helical assemblies as expected. The plentiful hydrogen-bonding sites and π···π interactions originating from the bioactive purin group of ligand H 2 L greatly contribute to the formation of helical structures and the structural dimension, showing an intriguing ability in the supramolecular assembly. At room temperature, complexes 1–6 exhibit solid-state photoluminescences, with their emission wavelengths and intensities varying according to the central metal ions and the coordination patterns of ligand H 2 L. Additionally, the thermostabilities of these new complexes have been discussed in detail. In particular, 3D polymers 5 and 6 have extra high thermostabilities and stronger blue emissions, indicating potential applications in photoluminescent materials.

elements.content: A serial of metallohelicates ranging from double helical chains to two−three-dimensional polymeric networks based on 1D metal−organic helixes of 2-(6-oxo-6,9-dihydro-1H-purin-1-yl) acetates (an acetate-functionalized purin derivative) has been synthesized and structurally determined. Solid-state properties, such as thermal stability, X-ray powder diffractions, and the photoluminescence properties at room temperature for these meso crystalline compounds have been investigated.

elements.content: Metal–organic coordination polymers, especially the helical structures, have attracted particular interest in coordination chemistry not only for their intriguing structures but also for their practical applications in molecular recognition, optical materials, biomimetic chemistry, asymmetric catalysis chemistry, enantiomorphic separation, and structural biology. Up to now, large numbers of single-, double-, and multistranded helical coordination polymers have been constructed. But controlling the helicity on a supramolecular level remains a big challenge for laboratory chemists. Therefore, it is still important to design appropriate ligands via promising synthetic routes for the construction of helical metal–organic complexes.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal-organic coordination polymers, especially the helical structures, have attracted particular interest in coordination chemistry not only for their intriguing structures but also for their practical applications in molecular recognition, optical materials, biomimetic chemistry, asymmetric catalysis chemistry, enantiomorphic separation, and structural biology. Up to now, large numbers of single-, double-, and multistranded helical coordination polymers have been constructed. But controlling the helicity on a supramolecular level remains a big challenge for laboratory chemists. Therefore, it is still important to design appropriate ligands via promising synthetic routes for the construction of helical metal-organic complexes.

elements.content: In general, helicity can be transmitted from helical organic compounds or induced from flexible bridges by noncovalent interactions in crystal engineering. It has been proven that the selection of flexible aromatic carboxylate ligands is very popular and promising in the design and synthesis of novel metal–organic helixes, owing to the coordination-assisted distortion of carboxyl from the conjugated backbone making the formation of helical coordination polymers easier. Very recently, we have communicated a new purine-containing carboxylic acid ligand, 2-(6-oxo-6,9-dihydro-1H-purin-1-yl)acetic acid (H 2 L), and its CoII and NiII coordination polymers. As a result, ligands H 2 L bridge metal nodes into 2D helical-constructed corrugated (4,4) sheets, where two helical conformations are stabilized by the stronger π···π stacking interactions between the purins of ligands H 2 L. Notably, through the acetate-functionalized modification, the bioactive purin derivative H 2 L not only increases the coordination and hydrogen-bonding sites but also improves flexibility, which is a key factor for the formation of metal–organic helixes. It was also interestingly observed by us that through the proton migration between the Nimidazole atoms, ligand H 2 L could tautomerize and transform into its tautomer 2-(6-oxo-6,7-dihydro-1H-purin-1-yl) acetic acid to make for a supramolecular assembly (see Figure S1 of the ).

It has been proven that the selection of flexible aromatic carboxylate ligands is very popular and promising in the design and synthesis of novel metal-organic helixes, owing to the coordination-assisted distortion of carboxyl from the conjugated backbone making the formation of helical coordination polymers easier. Very recently, we have communicated a new purine-containing carboxylic acid ligand, 2-(6-oxo-6,9-dihydro-1H-purin-1-yl)acetic acid (H  2  L), and its CoII and NiII coordination polymers. As a result, ligands H  2  L bridge metal nodes into 2D helical-constructed corrugated (4,4) sheets, where two helical conformations are stabilized by the stronger π⋅⋅⋅π stacking interactions between the purins of ligands H  2  L. Notably, through the acetate-functionalized modification, the bioactive purin derivative H  2  L not only increases the coordination and hydrogen-bonding sites but also improves flexibility, which is a key factor for the formation of metal-organic helixes. It was also interestingly observed by us that through the proton migration between the Nimidazole atoms, ligand H  2  L could tautomerize and transform into its tautomer 2-(6-oxo-6,7-dihydro-1H-purin-1-yl) acetic acid to make for a supramolecular assembly (see Figure S1 of the ).

elements.content: To continue our interest in the construction of novel metal–organic helical frameworks, we have been exploring the supramolecular chemistry of ligands H 2 L with other metal ions, such as lanthanide ions with a higher coordination number, and s2- and d-metal ions, PbII, ZnII, and CdII, with variable coordination number and geometry and optical property. We herein report the syntheses and determination of six new 1–3D helical coordination polymers, namely, [La(HL)2(NO3)(H2O)2] n (1), [Ce(HL)2(NO3)(H2O)2] n (2), [Pb(HL)2(H2O)2] n (3), [Cd(HL)2(H2O)2] n (4), [Cd(L)] n (5), and [Zn(L)] n (6). Interestingly, the hydrogen-bonding and π···π interactions between the purin groups of H 2 L greatly contribute to the helical structures of the resulting assemblies 1–6. Additionally, solid-state properties, such as thermal stabilities, X-ray powder diffractions, and the photoluminescence properties at room temperature for these meso crystalline compounds, have been investigated.

elements.content: All chemicals purchased were of reagent grade or better and used without further purification. Ligand H 2 L was synthesized according to literature. Element analyses were performed with a Carlo-Erba 1106 elemental analyzer. IR spectra (KBr pellets) were recorded on a Nicolet NEXUS 470 FT–IR spectrophotometer from 400 to 4000 cm–1. Thermal analysis curves were scanned from 30 to 800 °C under air on a STA 409 PC thermal analyzer. The fluorescent spectra were determined in solid state at room temperature on a Hitachi F-4500 fluorophotometer with a xenon arc lamp as the light source. The powered X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns of the samples were recorded by a RIGAKU-DMAX2500 X-ray diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and General Procedures

All chemicals purchased were of reagent grade or better and used without further purification. Ligand H  2  L was synthesized according to literature. Element analyses were performed with a Carlo-Erba 1106 elemental analyzer. IR spectra (KBr pellets) were recorded on a Nicolet NEXUS 470 FT-IR spectrophotometer from 400 to 4000 cm-1. Thermal analysis curves were scanned from 30 to 800 °C under air on a STA 409 PC thermal analyzer. The fluorescent spectra were determined in solid state at room temperature on a Hitachi F-4500 fluorophotometer with a xenon arc lamp as the light source. The powered X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns of the samples were recorded by a RIGAKU-DMAX2500 X-ray diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation.

elements.content: A mixture of H2O (8 mL), La(NO3)3·6H2O (0.0433 g, 0.1 mmol), and H 2 L (0.0388 g, 0.2 mmol) was adjusted to a pH value of 6–7 with aqueous ammonia. The resulting mixture was stirred for 10 min and then filtered with the filtrate evaporating under room temperature without disturbance. After 4 weeks, colorless block crystals 1 were obtained. Yield: 46.7 mg (75% based on La). Elemental analysis (%) calcd for C14H14LaN9O11: C, 26.96; H, 2.25; N, 20.22. Found: C, 27.12; H, 2.42; N, 20.05. elements.content: Suitable single crystals of 1–6 were selected for single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses. Crystallographic data of these crystals were collected at 291(2) K on a Xcalibur Eos Gemini CCD diffractometer equipped with a graphite crystal and incident beam monochromator using Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Raw data collection and reduction were done using CrysAlisPro. Empirical absorption correction was performed using spherical harmonics, implemented in a SCALE3 ABSPACK scaling algorithm. Structures were solved by direct method and refined by full-matrix least-squares on F 2 using SHELXTL. The nonhydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal parameters. The H atoms attached to C were generated geometrically with isotropic displacement parameters setting to 1.2 × U eq of the attached atoms. The H atoms attached to N and O were located from difference Fourier maps and treated as idealized contributions with isotropic displacement parameters setting to 1.2 × U eq and 1.5 × U eq of the attached atoms, respectively. Crystal data are summarized in detail in Table . Selected bond lengths and bond angles are listed in Table S1 of the . Hydrogen bond data of complexes 1–3 are listed in Table . The parameters of π···π interactions for all compounds are summarized in Table . Crystallographic data for the structural analyses have been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre, CCDC Nos. 948099–948104 for 1–6. Copies of this information may be obtained free of charge at www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/conts/retrieving.html or from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre, 12 Union Road, Cambridge CB21EZ, U.K. [Fax: (+44) 1223–336–033; E-mail: deposit@ccdc.cam.ac.uk.]

X-ray Structural Determination

Suitable single crystals of 1-6 were selected for single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses. Crystallographic data of these crystals were collected at 291(2) K on a Xcalibur Eos Gemini CCD diffractometer equipped with a graphite crystal and incident beam monochromator using Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Raw data collection and reduction were done using CrysAlisPro. Empirical absorption correction was performed using spherical harmonics, implemented in a SCALE3 ABSPACK scaling algorithm. Structures were solved by direct method and refined by full-matrix least-squares on F 2 using SHELXTL. The nonhydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal parameters. The H atoms attached to C were generated geometrically with isotropic displacement parameters setting to 1.2 × U eq of the attached atoms. The H atoms attached to N and O were located from difference Fourier maps and treated as idealized contributions with isotropic displacement parameters setting to 1.2 × U eq and 1.5 × U eq of the attached atoms, respectively. Crystal data are summarized in detail in Table . Selected bond lengths and bond angles are listed in Table S1 of the . Hydrogen bond data of complexes 1-3 are listed in Table . The parameters of π⋅⋅⋅π interactions for all compounds are summarized in Table . Crystallographic data for the structural analyses have been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre, CCDC Nos. 948099-948104 for 1-6. In this paper, there are four different synthesis methods used to synthesize complexes 1–6. During the experiment, we had tried to obtain all compounds in any of those methods, but it seems that the selected method for every determined complex is unique and not universally valid. The lanthanide complexes 1 and 2 were obtained through the traditional evaporation of the resulting aqueous solutions of lanthanide nitrate and H 2 L adjusted to a pH = 6–7 with aqueous ammonia, while complex 3 was hydrothermally synthesized through the reaction of PbCl2 and H 2 L with a drop of triethylamine to deprotonate at 110 °C. As for compound 4, it was obtained in a three-layered diffusion system with the aqueous solution of CdI2 as the bottom layer, the mixture of water and methanol as the mesosphere, and the aqueous solution of H 2 L adjusted to a pH = 6–7 with aqueous ammonia as the top layer. Comparatively, both crystals 5 and 6 were obtained through solvothermal reactions in water/DMF (volumetric ratio being 3:1) solutions at 120 °C without additional base for deprotonation. It was found that additional base for deprotonation in the syntheses of complexes 5 and 6 only resulted in precipitate. In order to obtain determinable crystals 6, a small amount of HBF4 in the reaction system is necessary to help crystallization. In combination with their crystal structures (vide infra), it can be inferred that the anionic states and coordination modes of ligands H 2 L are sensitive to reaction conditions, such as metal ions used, temperature, solvents, and pH values. The suitable pH for 1, 2, and 4 adjusted to 6–7 by aqueous ammonia and for 3 adjusted by triethylamine indicates that those of basicity only deprotonated the carboxylic acid of H 2 L to give an anionic state (HL)−. In particular, the syntheses of 5 and 6 provide interesting insight into the role of the hydro(solvo)thermal reaction condition upon the resulting structures. On the one hand, the higher temperature can increase the dissociation of the protons of the imidazole and the carboxyl groups in H 2 L and thereby form a doubly deprotonated ligand (L) 2– with a μ4-kN:kN′:kO:kO′ coordination mode. On the other hand, it makes for metal ions coordinating with more ligands (L)2– via the elimination of coordinated water from the coordination spheres under higher temperature.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Syntheses and Coordination Modes

In this paper, there are four different synthesis methods used to synthesize complexes 1-6. During the experiment, we had tried to obtain all compounds in any of those methods, but it seems that the selected method for every determined complex is unique and not universally valid. The lanthanide complexes 1 and 2 were obtained through the traditional evaporation of the resulting aqueous solutions of lanthanide nitrate and H  2  L adjusted to a pH = 6-7 with aqueous ammonia, while complex 3 was hydrothermally synthesized through the reaction of PbCl2 and H  2  L with a drop of triethylamine to deprotonate at 110 °C. As for compound 4, it was obtained in a three-layered diffusion system with the aqueous solution of CdI2 as the bottom layer, the mixture of water and methanol as the mesosphere, and the aqueous solution of H  2  L adjusted to a pH = 6-7 with aqueous ammonia as the top layer. Comparatively, both crystals 5 and 6 were obtained through solvothermal reactions in water/DMF (volumetric ratio being 3:1) solutions at 120 °C without additional base for deprotonation. It was found that additional base for deprotonation in the syntheses of complexes 5 and 6 only resulted in precipitate. In order to obtain determinable crystals 6, a small amount of HBF4 in the reaction system is necessary to help crystallization. In combination with their crystal structures (vide infra), it can be inferred that the anionic states and coordination modes of ligands H  2  L are sensitive to reaction conditions, such as metal ions used, temperature, solvents, and pH values. The suitable pH for 1, 2, and 4 adjusted to 6-7 by aqueous ammonia and for 3 adjusted by triethylamine indicates that those of basicity only deprotonated the carboxylic acid of H  2  L to give an anionic state (HL)-. In particular, the syntheses of 5 and 6 provide interesting insight into the role of the hydro(solvo)thermal reaction condition upon the resulting structures. On the one hand, the higher temperature can increase the dissociation of the protons of the imidazole and the carboxyl groups in H  2  L and thereby form a doubly deprotonated ligand (L) 2- with a μ4-kN:kN':kO:kO' coordination mode. On the other hand, it makes for metal ions coordinating with more ligands (L)2- via the elimination of coordinated water from the coordination spheres under higher temperature.

elements.content: The deprotonated ligands H 2 L in all those complexes act as bridges but display (HL)− and (L)2– anionic states and three different coordination modes A, B, and C presented in Scheme . In 1 and 2, lanthanide ions coordinate with O prior to N, and every (HL)− in coordination mode A bridges two lanthanide ions with the chelating carboxylate and Oamide. In 3 and 4, every (HL)− displays bis(monodentate) coordination mode B with one Ocarboxylate and Nimidazole atoms binding to metal centers. For complexes 5 and 6, doubly deprotonated ligands (L)2– adopt coordination mode C and act as four-connected spacers with two Ocarboxylate and two Nimidazole atoms bridging four metal nodes.
elements.clean_text: The deprotonated ligands H  2  L in all those complexes act as bridges but display (HL)- and (L)2- anionic states and three different coordination modes A, B, and C presented in Scheme . In 1 and 2, lanthanide ions coordinate with O prior to N, and every (HL)- in coordination mode A bridges two lanthanide ions with the chelating carboxylate and Oamide. In 3 and 4, every (HL)- displays bis(monodentate) coordination mode B with one Ocarboxylate and Nimidazole atoms binding to metal centers. For complexes 5 and 6, doubly deprotonated ligands (L)2- adopt coordination mode C and act as four-connected spacers with two Ocarboxylate and two Nimidazole atoms bridging four metal nodes.

elements.clean_text: 1  Schematic Representation of the Coordination Modes of Deprotonated Ligands H2L in Complexes 1-6

elements.content: Complexes 1 and 2 crystallize in the same space group P21/m and are isostructural. Their overall structures are 1D double helixes. For representation only, the structure of 1 is described in detail. As shown in Figure , the center LaIII is in an O10 coordination polyhedron ligated by four Ocarboxylate atoms from two chelating carboxylates of two ligands (HL)¯, two Oamide atoms from other two ligands (HL)¯, two O atoms from one chelating nitrate, and two O atoms from two water molecules, respectively. A mirror equally cut both the coordination polyhedron of the LaIII and the nitrate. The La–O bond lengths ranging from 2.504(4) to 2.690(2) Å are similar to those found in other reported LaIII complexes. In 1, the carboxylate and purin group of (HL)− are sharply distorted from a coplane with a dihedral angle being 106.2°. Every ligand (HL)− adopts the A coordination mode and bridges two LaIII centers to form a basic double-stranded helical chain of 1 with a separation distance of La···La being 7.971 Å. As presented in Figure a, the 1D double-stranded helical chains consist of bimetal rings formed by two (HL)− antiparallelly binding with two LaIII centers and the unsymmetrical angular ligands (HL)− cross-linked via LaIII centers extend along the b axis. In the 1D structure, left- and right-handed metal–organic helical chains share with the same metal nodes and wind around the same 21 axis with the helical pitch being 15.109 Å (Figure b). In 1, there are interesting hydrogen-bonding interactions (Table ). The intrachain hydrogen-bonding occurring among the adjacent coordination water O7 and the imidazole N1 of the ligands (HL)− probably fastens the metallohelicates (Figure S2 of the ). In the bc plane, those helical chains are connected into a 2D layer through regular interchain N···O hydrogen-bonding interactions originating from the imidazole N2 of ligands (HL)− in one double chain to the carboxylate O3 of ligands (HL)− in the adjacent double chain, and there are stronger interchain π···π interactions between the imidazoles of ligands (HL)− of adjacent chains in the same layer with a centroid-to-centroid distance of 3.355 Å (Figure and Figure S3 of the ). Through interlayer hydrogen-bonding interactions occurring from coordination water molecules, O6 in one layer to the N3 atoms of ligands (HL)− in the adjacent layer, those 2D layers extended into a 3D supramolecular network (Figure and Figure S4 of the ). Furthermore, there also exist stronger interlayer π···π interactions between the purines of ligands (HL)− of adjacent layers with a centroid-to-centroid distance being 3.583 Å (Figure and Figure S4 of the ). As described above, besides being a ditopic bridge ligand, every (HL)− anion in 1 not only uses uncoordinated Npurin atoms to form three hydrogen bonds but also stacks up through stronger π···π interactions between the purin groups of two adjacent (HL)− anions, displaying an intriguing ability in the supramolecular assembly.

Crystal Structures of Lanthanide Complexes 1 and 2 

Complexes 1 and 2 crystallize in the same space group P21/m and are isostructural. Their overall structures are 1D double helixes. For representation only, the structure of 1 is described in detail. As shown in Figure , the center LaIII is in an O10 coordination polyhedron ligated by four Ocarboxylate atoms from two chelating carboxylates of two ligands (HL)¯, two Oamide atoms from other two ligands (HL)¯, two O atoms from one chelating nitrate, and two O atoms from two water molecules, respectively. A mirror equally cut both the coordination polyhedron of the LaIII and the nitrate. The La-O bond lengths ranging from 2.504(4) to 2.690(2) Å are similar to those found in other reported LaIII complexes. In 1, the carboxylate and purin group of (HL)- are sharply distorted from a coplane with a dihedral angle being 106.2°. Every ligand (HL)- adopts the A coordination mode and bridges two LaIII centers to form a basic double-stranded helical chain of 1 with a separation distance of La⋅⋅⋅La being 7.971 Å. As presented in Figure a, the 1D double-stranded helical chains consist of bimetal rings formed by two (HL)- antiparallelly binding with two LaIII centers and the unsymmetrical angular ligands (HL)- cross-linked via LaIII centers extend along the b axis. In the 1D structure, left- and right-handed metal-organic helical chains share with the same metal nodes and wind around the same 21 axis with the helical pitch being 15.109 Å (Figure b). In 1, there are interesting hydrogen-bonding interactions (Table ). The intrachain hydrogen-bonding occurring among the adjacent coordination water O7 and the imidazole N1 of the ligands (HL)- probably fastens the metallohelicates (Figure S2 of the ). In the bc plane, those helical chains are connected into a 2D layer through regular interchain N⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen-bonding interactions originating from the imidazole N2 of ligands (HL)- in one double chain to the carboxylate O3 of ligands (HL)- in the adjacent double chain, and there are stronger interchain π⋅⋅⋅π interactions between the imidazoles of ligands (HL)- of adjacent chains in the same layer with a centroid-to-centroid distance of 3.355 Å (Figure  and Figure S3 of the ). Through interlayer hydrogen-bonding interactions occurring from coordination water molecules, O6 in one layer to the N3 atoms of ligands (HL)- in the adjacent layer, those 2D layers extended into a 3D supramolecular network (Figure  and Figure S4 of the ). Furthermore, there also exist stronger interlayer π⋅⋅⋅π interactions between the purines of ligands (HL)- of adjacent layers with a centroid-to-centroid distance being 3.583 Å (Figure  and Figure S4 of the ). As described above, besides being a ditopic bridge ligand, every (HL)- anion in 1 not only uses uncoordinated Npurin atoms to form three hydrogen bonds but also stacks up through stronger π⋅⋅⋅π interactions between the purin groups of two adjacent (HL)- anions, displaying an intriguing ability in the supramolecular assembly.

elements.content: Isomorphous complexes 3 and 4 are 2D coordination polymers, and isostructural complexes 5 and 6 are 3D coordination polymers. For representation, only the structures of compounds 3 and 5 are described in detail. Complex 3 crystallizes in the monoclinic P21/n space group. The asymmetrical unit consists of one-half PbII, one (HL)−, and one coordinated water molecule. Every PbII cation is ligated by four O atoms from the monodentate carboxylates of two (HL)− ligands and two water molecules and by two Nimidazole atoms from other two (HL)− ligands. The PbII atom sits on an inversion center i and has a slightly distorted N2O4 octahedron with four O atoms occupying the equatorial plane and two N atoms at the axial sites (Figure ). The Pb–O and Pb–N bonds fall in a normal range from 2.629(4) to 2.676(4) Å (Table S1 of the ). As for ligand (HL)−, the acetate group obviously distorts from the purin ring with a dihedral angle of 80.2°. In 3, each deprotonated ligand (HL)− adopts the B coordination mode and serves as an angular bis-connector to bridge planar nodes PbII with one Nimidazole and one Ocarboxyl and thereby forms a 2D puckered metal–organic layer of (4,4)-connected topology (Figure ). The separation distance of Pb···Pb bridged by ligand (HL)− is 9.021 Ǻ.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structures of Complexes 3-6

Isomorphous complexes 3 and 4 are 2D coordination polymers, and isostructural complexes 5 and 6 are 3D coordination polymers. For representation, only the structures of compounds 3 and 5 are described in detail. Complex 3 crystallizes in the monoclinic P21/n space group. The asymmetrical unit consists of one-half PbII, one (HL)-, and one coordinated water molecule. Every PbII cation is ligated by four O atoms from the monodentate carboxylates of two (HL)- ligands and two water molecules and by two Nimidazole atoms from other two (HL)- ligands. The PbII atom sits on an inversion center i and has a slightly distorted N2O4 octahedron with four O atoms occupying the equatorial plane and two N atoms at the axial sites (Figure ). The Pb-O and Pb-N bonds fall in a normal range from 2.629(4) to 2.676(4) Å (Table S1 of the ). As for ligand (HL)-, the acetate group obviously distorts from the purin ring with a dihedral angle of 80.2°. In 3, each deprotonated ligand (HL)- adopts the B coordination mode and serves as an angular bis-connector to bridge planar nodes PbII with one Nimidazole and one Ocarboxyl and thereby forms a 2D puckered metal-organic layer of (4,4)-connected topology (Figure ). The separation distance of Pb⋅⋅⋅Pb bridged by ligand (HL)- is 9.021 Ǻ.

elements.content: The structure feature of 3 is the 2D-corrugated helical framework constructed through HL-bridged left- and right-handed helical chains sharing the common PbII centers (Figure ) is very similar to the structures of our recently reported 2D CoII and NiII polymers of (HL)−. Those HL-bridged left- and right-handed metallohelicates run along their respective 21 axis with the helical pitches being 9.270 Å. In the 2D network of 3, each net contains two different helical conformations, which are stabilized not only through the stronger π···π stacking interaction between the two antiparallel purin groups in the net (the centroid-to-centroid distance being 3.427 Å) but also through doubly O···N hydrogen-bonding interactions originating from the coordination water O4 to the purin N3 of ligands (HL)− in the same net (Table ). As shown in Figure , those helical layers are extended into a 3D supramolecular network through interlayer Nimidazole···Ocarboxyl and Owater···Ocarboxyl hydrogen bonds (Table ). Notably, there are stronger interlayer π···π stacking interactions between the adjacent purin groups of ligands (HL)− with the edge-to-centroid distance being 3.227 Å. In 3 and 4, every ligand (HL)− not only acts as a bis(monodentate) bridge but also forms four hydrogen bonds and two-sorted π···π interactions, displaying attractive excellence in the formation of the 3D architectures, as observed in 1 and 2.

elements.content: Complex 5 crystallizes in the space group P21/c, and its asymmetrical unit is composed of one CdII and one ligand (L)2–. Each CdII center lies in a distorted tetrahedron coordinated by two N atoms and two O atoms from four different (L)2– ligands (Figure ). The bond lengths of Cd–N and Cd–O range from 2.186(11) to 2.232(9) Å, similar to those found in literature. Comparatively, those bond lengths of Cd–N/O for the tetrahedrally coordinated CdII in 5 are shorter than those found for octahedrally coordinated CdII in 4 [the Cd–N/O in 4 being in a range from 2.313(8)–2.390(8) Å, Table S1 of the ).

elements.content: Complex 5 is a 3D honeycomblike coordination polymer. In 5, every doubly deprotonated ligand (L)2– in the C coordination mode acts as a 4-connector to link four metal atoms CdII with two Nimidazole atoms and two Ocarboxylate atoms. The dihedral angle of carboxylate and purin group in (L)2– is 79.2°, similar to that found in 3. As shown in Figure , ligands (L)2– only use their Nimidazole atoms (N1 and N2) to bridge metal centers CdII into b axially extended metallohelicates with the 21 helical pitches being 10.701 Å and those homochiral chains are further linked by the carboxylate O3 atoms of ligands (L)2– into 2D homochiral layers. In the layer, the separation distances of Cd···Cd bridged by the ligand (L)2– are 6.393, 9.141, and 10.439 Å, respectively. Every homochiral 2D layer further bridges with its enantiomers up and down through the carboxylate O2 atoms of ligands (L)2– and in this way to produce a meso compound of a 3D network (Figure a). The separation distance of Cd···Cd bridged by the carboxylate of ligand (L)2– is 4.471 Å. In the architecture of 5, both the metal nodes CdII and ligands (L)2– can be simplified as 4-connectors, and thus, the resulting structure is symbolized as a 3D 4-connected (4, 63, 82) topological network (Figure b).

elements.content: As observed by the crystallographic data, the structural motifs of coordination polymers 1–6 vary from the 1D chain to the 3D network, with the changes of metal centers and coordination modes of H 2 L. In 1 and 2, the ten-coordinated LaIII and CeIII ions are cross-linked into the double-stranded helical chains through the bis-connectors (HL)− in the coordination mode A (μ-kO,O′:kO″), respectively. In 3 and 4, six-coordinated metal centers PbII and CdII acting as planar nodes are bridged by ligands (HL)− in the bis(monodentate) coordination mode B (μ-kO:kN) to form 2D helical networks, respectively. As for 5 and 6, the four-coordinated CdII and ZnII ions adopt tetrahedral coordination spheres and are bridged into 3D coordination polymers through the 4-connectors (L)2– in the coordination mode C (μ4-kN:kN′:kO:kO′), respectively. Our results indicate that the dimensionality of the resulting polymers increases with the coordination numbers of metal centers reducing from 10 to 4. Generally, the higher coordination numbers have a tendency to form higher dimensional frameworks, but in our case, it is reversed partially due to the terminal ligands such as nitrates and water molecules occupying some coordination sites around ten-coordinated lanthanide ions and six-coordinated metal centers PbII and CdII to limit their dimensionality. Apart from the influence of the metal coordination, the variously structural motifs of complexes 1–6 also result from the coordination modes of H 2 L, which mainly depend on the anionic states of ligands H 2 L which are related to the pH value and especially to the temperature of the reaction conditions.

Thermal Stability Analysis (TGA) and Powder X-ray Diffraction (PXRD)

To estimate the thermal stability of compounds 1-6, their thermal gravimetric analyses were carried out under air atmosphere from 30 to 800 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C min-1, and the results are given in Figure .

elements.content: Both complexes 1 and 2 are stable below 197 °C. On further heating, compound 1 began to decompose rapidly until 720 °C with remaining residue of 26.96% ascribed to be La2O3 (calcd 26.14%). For 2, a slow decomposition occurred from 197 to 380 °C and then a successive sharp weight loss followed, up to 460 °C. The remaining residue of 28.82% is considered to be CeO2 (calcd 27.56%). For complex 3, the dehydration process occurred at 180–250 °C with a weight loss of 4.85%, corresponding to the removal of the coordination water molecules (calcd 5.71%), and then a successive mass loss occurred from 350 to 555 °C, indicating the complete decomposition of the compound. As for the resulting residue of 36.58%, it is presumed to be PbO (calcd 35.46%). The dehydration process of 4 began at a lower temperature of 120 °C, and on further heating, it suffered a weight loss of 7.70%, up to 250 °C, corresponding to the removal of coordination water molecules (calcd 6.73%). From 300 to 685 °C, compound 4 completely decomposed with the residue of 25.56% presumed to be CdO (calcd 24.01%). Comparatively, 3D polymers 5 and 6 have exceptional heat resistance. Both compounds are stable up to 487 and 415 °C, respectively. As overtaken by their heat-resisting temperatures, the samples of 5 and 6 suffered one step decomposition processes. In the crucibles, the remains of 42.14% for 5 and 31.06% for 6 may be CdO (calcd 42.17%) and ZnO (calcd 31.60%), respectively.

elements.content: TGA results disclose that complexes 5 and 6 have unusually excellent thermotolerance. Apart from the thermal stability, the phase purity of the prepared bulk material also plays a key role upon the functionality of the devices. Thus, further powered X-ray diffraction (PXRD) measurements were used to determine the phase purity of compounds 5 and 6. The experimental and simulated PXRD patterns of the both complexes are shown in Figure . The calculated PXRD patterns from the single-crystal X-ray diffraction data are in agreement with the observed ones, indicating the phase purity of those synthesized crystalline products. The differences in intensity may be due to the preferred orientation of the powder samples.

elements.content: In the past decade, photoluminescence properties of lanthanide and d10 metal coordination compounds have been extensively investigated, owing to their potential applications in lighting, fluorescent sensors, multimodal imaging and optical devices, as well as for their photochemistry. Therefore, in the present work, the solid-state luminescent properties of lanthanide complexes 1–2 and CdII and ZnII complexes 4–6 were investigated at room temperature. Owing to the nonradiative exchange of the electronic energy of the lanthanide(III) ion to the high vibration modes of O–H bond, both lanthanide complexes 1 and 2 can emit very weak fluorescences with the negligible changes of the curve shapes and maximum peak positions in comparison with those of free ligand H 2 L upon excitation at 395 nm (Figure S5 of the ). As for compounds 4–6, they exhibit photoluminescences centered at 395, 453, and 417 nm upon excitation at 330, 356, and 351 nm, respectively (Figure ). Compared with the emission of the free ligand H 2 L center at 462 nm, as excited with the light of 395 nm, the emissions of complexes 4–6 undergo a blue shift by 67, 9, and 45 nm, respectively, and their emission intensities, especially for 3D coordination polymers 5 and 6, are obviously enhanced. On the basis of the emission shapes which are similar to that of the free ligand H 2 L, as well as the slight or moderate wavelength shifts, the complex emissions are tentatively ascribed to metal-perturbed intraligand emissions as observed in the other complexes of d10 metals. Perhaps the enhanced emission intensities for those complexes are due to the bridge coordination of deprotonated ligands H 2 L in the resulting polymers, which increases the rigidity of ligands (HL)−/(L)2– and thus reduces the nonradioactive relaxation process. Notably, the two cadmium(II) compounds 4 and 5 have distinctly different emissions. The blue emission of the 3D coordination polymer 5 has a red shift of 58 nm and about twice the intensity compared with the purple emission of 2D coordination polymer 4. Although the emissions of both cadmium(II) compounds mainly originate from the intraligand π* → π emissions of ligands H 2 L, their emission intensity and color strongly depend on their structural features. Probably, the structural differences in 4 and 5 such as the dimensions of coordination polymers, the coordination spheres of CdII, and the coordination patterns of ligands H 2 L produce an obvious influence upon the intraligand π* → π emissions of ligands H 2 L.
elements.clean_text:
Photoluminescence Properties

In the past decade, photoluminescence properties of lanthanide and d10 metal coordination compounds have been extensively investigated, owing to their potential applications in lighting, fluorescent sensors, multimodal imaging and optical devices, as well as for their photochemistry. Therefore, in the present work, the solid-state luminescent properties of lanthanide complexes 1-2 and CdII and ZnII complexes 4-6 were investigated at room temperature. Owing to the nonradiative exchange of the electronic energy of the lanthanide(III) ion to the high vibration modes of O-H bond, both lanthanide complexes 1 and 2 can emit very weak fluorescences with the negligible changes of the curve shapes and maximum peak positions in comparison with those of free ligand H  2  L upon excitation at 395 nm (Figure S5 of the ). As for compounds 4-6, they exhibit photoluminescences centered at 395, 453, and 417 nm upon excitation at 330, 356, and 351 nm, respectively (Figure ). Compared with the emission of the free ligand H  2  L center at 462 nm, as excited with the light of 395 nm, the emissions of complexes 4-6 undergo a blue shift by 67, 9, and 45 nm, respectively, and their emission intensities, especially for 3D coordination polymers 5 and 6, are obviously enhanced. On the basis of the emission shapes which are similar to that of the free ligand H  2  L, as well as the slight or moderate wavelength shifts, the complex emissions are tentatively ascribed to metal-perturbed intraligand emissions as observed in the other complexes of d10 metals. Perhaps the enhanced emission intensities for those complexes are due to the bridge coordination of deprotonated ligands H  2  L in the resulting polymers, which increases the rigidity of ligands (HL)-/(L)2- and thus reduces the nonradioactive relaxation process. Notably, the two cadmium(II) compounds 4 and 5 have distinctly different emissions. The blue emission of the 3D coordination polymer 5 has a red shift of 58 nm and about twice the intensity compared with the purple emission of 2D coordination polymer 4. Although the emissions of both cadmium(II) compounds mainly originate from the intraligand π* → π emissions of ligands H  2  L, their emission intensity and color strongly depend on their structural features. Probably, the structural differences in 4 and 5 such as the dimensions of coordination polymers, the coordination spheres of CdII, and the coordination patterns of ligands H  2  L produce an obvious influence upon the intraligand π* → π emissions of ligands H  2  L.

elements.content: In addition, we also studied the photoluminescence property of s2-metal PbII complex 3 in the solid state at room temperature (Figure ). Compound 3 emits bright green light with a maximum centered at 517 nm upon excitation at 450 nm, whose wavelength is red shifted by 55 nm when compared to the emission of the free ligand H 2 L. The nature of the broad and red-shifted emission band may be tentatively ascribed to the contribution of ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT), which leads to the rearrangement of energy levels. Especially, the emission shape, wavelength, and intensity of 3 are significantly different from those of isostructural 4 of CdII.

elements.content: Complexes 1–6 exhibit solid-state emissions, with the colors varying from violet to green and the maximum wavelengths varying in a large range of 395–517 nm. Those photoluminescent compounds allow the emission wavelengths and intensities to be interestingly modulated by the central metal ions and the coordination patterns of ligand H 2 L. In particular, 3D polymers 5 and 6 with stronger blue emissions may have potential applications in various optoelectronic devices due to the extra high thermostabilities.

elements.content: In summary, a serial of metallohelicates have been successfully synthesized through the use of the designed purin-containing ligand H 2 L. Acetate-functionalized purin-containing ligand H 2 L has been experimentally confirmed herein in the productive formation of various helical coordination polymers varying from the double helical chains of 1 and 2 and the 2D helical networks of 3 and 4 to the 3D coordination polymers of 5 and 6 containing 2D homochiral layers based on 1D metal–organic helixes. In those meso compounds, ligands H 2 L display different anionic states, bridge modes, and especially unsymmetrical configurations with a sharp distortion between the acetate and purin (the dihedral angle ranging from 79.2 to 107.2°), in favor of constructing helical assemblies. In addition, the plentiful hydrogen-bonding sites and π···π interactions originating from the bioactive purin group of ligand H 2 L greatly contribute to the formation of helical structures and the structural dimension, showing an intriguing ability in the supramolecular assembly. At room temperature, complexes 1–6 exhibit solid-state photoluminescences, with their emission wavelengths and intensities varying according to the central metal ions and the coordination patterns of ligand H 2 L. Particularly, 3D polymers 5 and 6 have extra high thermostabilities and stronger blue emissions, indicating potential applications in photoluminescent materials. Further work related to the syntheses of novel multifunctional metal–organic hybrid materials from this kind of bioactive purin-containing carboxylate is underway in our laboratory.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, a serial of metallohelicates have been successfully synthesized through the use of the designed purin-containing ligand H  2  L. Acetate-functionalized purin-containing ligand H  2  L has been experimentally confirmed herein in the productive formation of various helical coordination polymers varying from the double helical chains of 1 and 2 and the 2D helical networks of 3 and 4 to the 3D coordination polymers of 5 and 6 containing 2D homochiral layers based on 1D metal-organic helixes. In those meso compounds, ligands H  2  L display different anionic states, bridge modes, and especially unsymmetrical configurations with a sharp distortion between the acetate and purin (the dihedral angle ranging from 79.2 to 107.2°), in favor of constructing helical assemblies. In addition, the plentiful hydrogen-bonding sites and π⋅⋅⋅π interactions originating from the bioactive purin group of ligand H  2  L greatly contribute to the formation of helical structures and the structural dimension, showing an intriguing ability in the supramolecular assembly. At room temperature, complexes 1-6 exhibit solid-state photoluminescences, with their emission wavelengths and intensities varying according to the central metal ions and the coordination patterns of ligand H  2  L. Particularly, 3D polymers 5 and 6 have extra high thermostabilities and stronger blue emissions, indicating potential applications in photoluminescent materials. Further work related to the syntheses of novel multifunctional metal-organic hybrid materials from this kind of bioactive purin-containing carboxylate is underway in our laboratory.

cln_elements.content:
A mixture of H2O (8 mL), La(NO3)3·6H2O (0.0433 g, 0.1 mmol), and H 2 L (0.0388 g, 0.2 mmol) was adjusted to a pH value of 6–7 with aqueous ammonia. The resulting mixture was stirred for 10 min and then filtered with the filtrate evaporating under room temperature without disturbance. After 4 weeks, colorless block crystals 1 were obtained. cln_elements.content: Both complexes 1 and 2 are stable below 197 °C. On further heating, compound 1 began to decompose rapidly until 720 °C with remaining residue of 26.96% ascribed to be La2O3 (calcd 26.14%). For 2, a slow decomposition occurred from 197 to 380 °C and then a successive sharp weight loss followed, up to 460 °C. The remaining residue of 28.82% is considered to be CeO2 (calcd 27.56%). For complex 3, the dehydration process occurred at 180–250 °C with a weight loss of 4.85%, corresponding to the removal of the coordination water molecules (calcd 5.71%), and then a successive mass loss occurred from 350 to 555 °C, indicating the complete decomposition of the compound. As for the resulting residue of 36.58%, it is presumed to be PbO (calcd 35.46%). The dehydration process of 4 began at a lower temperature of 120 °C, and on further heating, it suffered a weight loss of 7.70%, up to 250 °C, corresponding to the removal of coordination water molecules (calcd 6.73%). From 300 to 685 °C, compound 4 completely decomposed with the residue of 25.56% presumed to be CdO (calcd 24.01%). Comparatively, 3D polymers 5 and 6 have exceptional heat resistance. Both compounds are stable up to 487 and 415 °C, respectively. As overtaken by their heat-resisting temperatures, the samples of 5 and 6 suffered one step decomposition processes. In the crucibles, the remains of 42.14% for 5 and 31.06% for 6 may be CdO (calcd 42.17%) and ZnO (calcd 31.60%), respectively.
